text: So this is more or less what you should have in front of you now very very basic just a simple footprint chart You know, maybe your colors are different to mine. That's fine. Okay I'm going to show you how you can change all of that now in a minute Okay So if you want to make changes to the preferences of your overall system, you would obviously click on the top left Yeah, that would be effectively your default setting. So you can see if we came to the chart preferences we can start off here by looking at some of the the defaults that it's currently set to. Okay so just very briefly obviously grid lines that is something that annoys certain traders and it doesn't annoy other traders. For me I quite like having some sort of grid lines maybe a solid major and minor division and if I apply you'll see simply it's just creating some form of a scale on the In terms of other things you can have a look at, what I would say is obviously just make sure... Just make sure that, in terms of the labels and values, make sure that if you want display boxes, as you can see in the top left and the bottom left corners, if you want those display boxes, you can see that we've got them listed here under display value box. So you can untick them if you want and simply remove them. And again, a lot of this is just play around. It's more preference more than anything. So if you want it there, include it. If you don't, don't. Obviously as you're making changes in terms of the setup here, this will be your default settings as you go through. One of the last things to pay attention to is this button called continuation. It is quite important now. Continuation is just simply, obviously when futures contracts roll over, in other words they move into the forward dated month, continuation will effectively continue showing you the price and it will automatically show you the market or the month that's trading Okay, now obviously you can see the system default is to have no continuation. In other words, what will happen is you will have your chart come the end of the month, will stop showing data or it won't roll itself automatically. So for me, I suggest you unclick the no continuation and again I would suggest that you go and click the active rollover when trading activity and optionally equalize closes. the contract will automatically roll, the software will automatically put you in the front month as soon as the volume in the front month is more than the volume in the current month. So for me I recommend that, obviously there are other options you can utilize but we're going to utilize active rollover in terms of when the volume moves. So that's what you want to look at in terms of the system. Now the next part we're going to move on to again We're going to come up to the set of the setup and we're going to talk a little bit about some of the sorry some of the

Now, one of the features that's really good about this tool is that when you do find a feature that you really like, let's say for instance you've created all your charts, you've been utilizing it for a couple of months and then you all of a sudden want to make a change to all of your charts or some of your charts, you can simply come in as bottom right here and you can apply it to this chart on this page, you can apply it to all your charts on this page, you can apply it to all your charts on all pages and you can apply it to all new charts. you can make changes relatively easy on all your charts, some of your charts, some of your pages, etc. So don't worry if right now you don't get everything perfectly, at a later stage you can come back and make changes across all of your charts in one go as opposed to having to do them all individually. text: Now a lot of traders on the Axia floor do still print their charts to look at them, to annotate them, to draw on them, to really sort of spend time just focused on the numbers and not being distracted by other things. However obviously if you're someone that's a little bit paper conscious and you prefer to not waste paper, you can simply get a snipping tool. Now if you go to your start on your computer and you type in snipping tool you'll find that most computers nowadays have some form of a snipping tool and you can simply just go new and you can simply just select the region you want, draw all over it, make a nice tick, talk about certain imbalances etc etc, right click, copy the picture and paste it into either a Word document or as you'll see an Evernote document as Okay, then in terms of the next tool. This is called a magnet tool. Now... The magnet tool is something that works particularly well, not so much in the footprint, but what it does effectively is a lot of the time when we select a line, for instance as I've done here, we might not get close enough to the price we're looking at, maybe to a previous high or a previous low or maybe a trend line. So what the magnet does is it effectively, it attaches itself, so if I'm hovering maybe As soon as you click on it you can set the level of magnetism within the tool and you can see it asks for magnet strength. It's advised that you set it at at least 50. This makes it relatively sensitive and will at least find the price that it's looking for. For the footprint, it's better suited to the candlestick charts, so we won't really be utilizing it much in the footprint tool. Now something that really came of interest to me, and I'm going to share this with you, I'm going to bring back the Evernote, is that, okay, for me, I'd never known what the magnet button did. This is effected throughout the course. These are the colors I'm going to utilize. Now I'm going to go through them and I'm going to plot them on the chart for you and show you how to change them. So I effectively have seven different colors. Now again you don't have to adopt these color scheme. You can adopt your own color scheme. You might not even like the idea or the principle behind the color scheme. But the reason I have it's very simple. Every one of these colors is identifying something for me so that I can effectively execute one of the 10 strategies you're going to learn. Now for me, brown colors represent daily highs and lows. So whenever there's a daily high and low in my debrief the previous day, I go and put those brown lines in to show me the daily high and low. Now obviously that's very effective for breakout trading or for extensions on previous days highs or maybe potential imbalance strategies. In terms of pink, you'll see a bright pink simply indicates the weekly high and low. In terms of red, these are just very important reference points, so any kind of points of reference that I thought were valid from the previous day, let's say for instance we had a key economic data piece, European CPI, I would always put a reference point that was left as a result of that economic data, okay? Again, the reason I do this is just that it's a reference point, it's drawing my attention to this having been quite an important reference on economic data. Then orange, I utilize for high absorption, again, you know, I've spoken a little bit about this in Unit 3, what absorption is, what it looks like, and you'll see me talk about this extensively throughout the strategy sessions. So for me, I use orange to signal where there's been some really high absorption or really, really big delta shifts in price. Okay, in terms of dark blue, this would signal really key breakout areas. Now when we talk about the breakout strategy right towards the end of the course, you know obviously this, you know, breakouts, we tend to use a couple of different charts, not just a footprint. So for me, identifying the breakouts, I always like to put a nice dark blue line. So that signals number one, I don't want to go against the break of that blue line. But equally, I want to make sure that when that break occurs, I'm watching that price action around the blue line quite closely. Turquoise shows us where there's an initiative. So it shows us where someone has stepped in, either a buyer or seller, and they're stepping in in an aggressive manner. And then obviously green shows me any kind of imbalances in the market.
